perturbation.original_text: 11. Mutual Representations, Warranties and Covenants - Each party (the "Warranting Party"), to induce the other party to enter into this Agreement, represents, warrants and covenants that: (a) the Warranting Party has the full right and authority, and possesses all licenses, permits, authorizations and rights to intellectual property required to enter into this Agreement and to perform the acts required of it hereunder; (b) the performance by the Warranting Party pursuant to this Agreement and/or the rights in this Agreement granted to the other party will not conflict with or result in a breach or violation of any of the terms or provisions, or constitute a default under any agreement by which the Warranting Party is bound; and (c) with respect to the performance of its obligations hereunder, the Warranting Party will comply with all applicable laws, rules and regulation.
perturbation.changed_text: 11. Mutual Representations, Warranties and Covenants - Each party (the "Warranting Party"), to induce the other party to enter into this Agreement, represents, warrants and covenants that: (a) the Warranting Party has the full right and authority, and possesses all licenses, permits, authorizations and rights to intellectual property required to enter into this Agreement and to perform the acts required of it hereunder; (b) the performance by the Warranting Party pursuant to this Agreement and/or the rights in this Agreement granted to the other party will not conflict with or result in a breach or violation of any of the terms or provisions, or constitute a default under any agreement by which the Warranting Party is bound.
perturbation.explanation: By removing subsection (c), the agreement no longer explicitly warrants compliance with all applicable laws, rules, and regulations. This creates a legal risk, as such compliance is generally implied and often legally required, especially in areas like advertising and product safety. The omission introduces ambiguity and weakens the consumer protection implicitly afforded by warranting legal compliance.
perturbation.contradicted_law: Various consumer protection laws and advertising regulations, including but not limited to the Illinois Consumer Fraud and Deceptive Business Practices Act.

perturbation.original_text: 7. Representation - Individual represents and warrants that any testimonial or review provided reflects her own honest opinions, findings, beliefs, or experiences. Individual represents that she is a bona fide user of Lifeway products and/or services.
perturbation.changed_text: 7. Representation - Individual represents that she is a user of Lifeway products and/or services.
perturbation.explanation: By removing 'warrants that any testimonial or review provided reflects her own honest opinions, findings, beliefs, or experiences' and replacing with 'represents', there is no guarantee of truthfulness regarding individual opinions. This creates a legal risk because consumer protection laws (e.g., those enforced by the FTC) require endorsements to reflect honest opinions and experiences. The removal of the warranty weakens the agreement's protection against false advertising claims. The inclusion of 'bona fide' has also been removed.
perturbation.contradicted_law: Federal Trade Commission (FTC) Endorsement Guides; Illinois Consumer Fraud and Deceptive Business Practices Act.

perturbation.original_text: 3. perturbation.changed_text: 3. Release - Individual hereby releases and discharges Lifeway from any and all claims, demands, or causes of action in law or equity that he or she may have or may hereafter acquire, including without limitation in connection with any prior use, reuse, publication, reproduction, performance, copy, creation of derivative works, exhibition, broadcast, and display of the name, image and likeness of Individual.
perturbation.explanation: By removing 'any and all claims for libel, slander, invasion of privacy, copyright or trademark violation, right of publicity, or false light, that may arise out of or in connection with the use of the Marketing Materials in accordance with this Agreement.', the contract is no longer releasing Lifeway from liability claims pertaining to libel, privacy, copyright, trademark and publicity. These are potential causes of action that the individual could bring against Lifeway, and releasing them would protect Lifeway from litigation. Removing that clause leaves Lifeway exposed to liability, meaning they're not protected under the state law.
perturbation.contradicted_law: Illinois Compiled Statutes Chapter 815. Business Transactions; 505/2. Fraudulent practices.
